comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: See also: Excavation at York Street North for Shore Local Tracks from Three Crowns Hotel (17.02.1927) [SRNSW: Digital ID: 12685_a007_a00704_8724000023r.jpg] Curious to know the definition of 'shore local tracks'?

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] III.—CONSTRUCTION OP THE SOUTHERN APPROACH. During the year work has been augmented and is now proceeding over the whole section from the south end of Dorman, Long & Co.'s contract to the north end of Wynyard Station. (a) Tunnels. The double track tunnel for the Shore local tracks under Jamison street was completed, while the double track tunnel for the Shore tracks was partly excavated and a commencement made with the concreting. Both of these tunnels are in poor rock, having little cover, consequently heavy timbering was necessary. (/)) Excavation. The total quantity of excavation was 86,136 cubic vards, tho principal items being tho Jamison street to Grosvenor-street cutting, 11,6.32 cubic yards, the Grosvenor-street to Essex-street cutting, 26,(183 cubic yards, and between Argyle-street and the end of the contract, 35,658 cubic yards. (c) Concrete work. The cut and cover work on the new Scots Church site was completed and the site was ready for the Scots Church authorities on 30th June, 1928, as promised. Excerpt from REPORT OF THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 30th JUNE, 1928,

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I'd conjecture that the "shore local" tracks,  were the ones which were used by the trams.  If you were going to make a distinction,  the actual tracks would be the "shore main" tracks because ( in the context ),  they would be the main tracks having the through connection to central and hornsby.

comment.author: 79583367@N02
comment._content:
This is an amazing photo.  I've never seen shots in this area before.  It looks like it's looking south on York Street, from about what is now Lang Park, with Scots Church on the left, Town Hall tower in the centre distance, and St Philips Church on the right.
So, is this the railway (western) tunnel excavation, or the tramway (eastern) tunnel?

Or both perhaps, as they were quite close together at this point.
